caption: (a) Pre-flop Train Set
description: This figure shows the distribution of actions in the pre-flop training set of the POKERBENCH dataset.  The actions are categorized as raise, fold, call, and check, and the bars represent the proportion of each action in the dataset.  This visualization helps to understand the balance of actions in the training data which is essential for training robust poker-playing AI models.

caption: (b) Post-flop Train Set
description: The figure is a bar chart showing the distribution of actions (raise, fold, call, check, bet) in the training set for the post-flop phase of poker games.  The data illustrates the relative frequency of each action taken during the training of a large language model (LLM) for playing poker. This provides insight into the types of decisions the model is trained on and the overall balance of actions in the training data.

caption: (c) Pre-flop Benchmark
description: This figure shows the distribution of actions (fold, call, check, raise) in the pre-flop scenarios of the POKERBENCH benchmark.  It visually represents the proportion of each action type present in the pre-flop game examples used for evaluating large language models (LLMs) on their poker-playing abilities. The distribution is designed to be balanced, unlike real-world poker games where folding is more common, to ensure fair evaluation of LLMs across different action types.

caption: (d) Post-flop Benchmark
description: This figure shows the distribution of actions (fold, call, check, bet, raise) in the post-flop scenarios of the POKERBENCH benchmark dataset.  It visually represents the frequency or proportion of each action type in the benchmark's post-flop game examples, providing insights into the balance and variety of gameplay situations included in this part of the dataset.

caption: Figure 1: Action distributions. (a) and (b) show the training dataset distribution, while (c) and (d) show the distribution for hands selected to be part of the PokerBench Benchmark.
description: This figure displays the distribution of actions (fold, call, check, bet, raise) in the PokerBench dataset.  Subfigures (a) and (b) illustrate the action distributions in the training set for pre-flop and post-flop scenarios respectively.  Subfigures (c) and (d) show the action distributions specifically for the hands chosen to be included in the PokerBench benchmark, which is used for evaluating LLMs' poker playing abilities. This highlights the differences in action frequency between the full training data and the curated benchmark subset.

caption: Figure 2: Training dyanmics of Llama-3-8B on PokerBench training dataset.
description: This figure displays the training dynamics of the Llama-3-8B model on the PokerBench training dataset.  It shows the training loss, validation loss, pre-flop training EM accuracy, pre-flop testing EM accuracy, post-flop training EM accuracy, and post-flop testing EM accuracy over the course of 5000 optimization steps.  The plot illustrates how the model's performance on both pre-flop and post-flop scenarios improved during training, as indicated by decreasing loss and increasing accuracy.

caption: (a) Single Broadway Dry
description: This figure shows a sample Texas Hold'em poker hand categorized as a 'Single Broadway Dry' board texture.  This specific texture is characterized by the presence of exactly one high-value card (Broadway card: Ten, Jack, Queen, King, or Ace) on the flop, along with two lower-value cards, and a lack of potential for immediate strong hands like flushes or straights. The example hand shown helps illustrate the concept of board textures used to group and analyze similar scenarios within the POKERBENCH benchmark.

caption: (b) Single Broadway Wet
description: This figure shows a specific type of flop (the first three community cards dealt in Texas Hold'em poker) categorized as 'Single Broadway Wet'.  A 'Broadway' card refers to one of the high-value cards (Ten, Jack, Queen, King, Ace). 'Single' indicates only one such card appears on the flop. 'Wet' signifies the flop has a good potential to make strong hands (like flushes or straights), increasing the action and excitement of the hand.  The image visually represents this flop with the specific cards shown, illustrating this category of board texture within the POKERBENCH dataset.

caption: (c) Double Broadway
description: This figure shows a sample board texture in Texas Hold'em poker, specifically a 'Double Broadway' type.  A 'Double Broadway' board texture is characterized by the presence of two high-value cards (Ten or higher) among the community cards (flop) dealt during the game.  This type of board often presents many strong potential hands, leading to complex betting strategies.

caption: (d) Triple Broadway
description: This figure shows a specific type of flop (the first three community cards dealt in Texas Hold'em poker) categorized as a "Triple Broadway" in the POKERBENCH dataset.  A Triple Broadway flop consists of three high-value cards (Ten or higher) from different suits, creating a dynamic situation with multiple potential winning hands.  This type of flop is particularly interesting because it offers many different strategic possibilities for players, including the potential for bluffs and strong bets depending on the players' hole cards.

caption: (e) Mid Dry
description: This figure shows a sample poker board from the POKERBENCH dataset, classified as a "Mid Dry" board texture.  "Mid" refers to the rank of the cards (neither high nor low), and "Dry" indicates that the board doesn't offer many strong drawing possibilities (like a flush or straight draw). This particular board is likely to lead to less complex betting situations compared to boards with strong draws, making it representative of a common type of game situation in Texas Hold'em poker.

caption: (f) Dynamic
description: This figure shows a sample of a flop (the first three community cards dealt in Texas Hold'em poker) classified as a "Dynamic" board texture in the POKERBENCH dataset.  Dynamic board textures represent situations where the best hand is not yet determined, but has a high probability of developing as the game progresses.  This type of flop often creates exciting and complex strategic situations in the game.

caption: (g) Very Wet/Dynamic
description: This figure shows a sample board texture in Texas Hold'em poker.  The term 'very wet' refers to a board that offers many opportunities for players to make strong hands (e.g., flushes or straights). 'Dynamic' means there's a high likelihood of further strong hands developing as more community cards are revealed. This particular board (9♥ 8♥ 7♥) is wet because it contains three hearts, giving players with heart-suited cards a significant advantage. It is dynamic as a fourth heart would complete a flush.

caption: (h) Low
description: This figure shows a sample of a low board texture in Texas Hold'em poker.  A low board texture is characterized by community cards that are numerically low (typically 2-7), making it less likely to create strong hands like flushes or straights.  These types of boards often lead to more complex strategic decisions as players have fewer opportunities to make strong hands.  The specific hand shown (6♣3♣4♥2♦) is an example of such a low texture board.

caption: (i) Monotone
description: This figure shows example board textures used to filter post-flop search space. Specifically, image (i) shows a "monotone" texture, where all three community cards are of the same suit.  This is one of several board texture categories (e.g., single broadway dry, single broadway wet, etc.) used in the POKERBENCH dataset to create a balanced representation of various game scenarios.

caption: (j) Paired Dry
description: This figure shows a sample poker board texture in the context of the POKERBENCH benchmark.  Specifically, it depicts a "Paired Dry" texture, which indicates a flop where two cards share the same rank (a pair), but the overall board lacks many opportunities to create strong hands like flushes or straights. This type of board is less likely to result in large pots, and the strategic considerations are different from boards with more potential for high-value hands. The image itself displays a visual representation of such a board.

caption: (k) Paired Dynamic
description: This figure shows one example of the board textures used to classify flops for filtering the post-flop search space.  Specifically, this image depicts a paired dynamic board texture. A paired dynamic texture is characterized by the presence of a pair of cards of the same rank and other cards that increase the potential for making a strong hand, such as a straight or flush.

caption: Figure 3: Different board textures used to classify flops for filtering post-flop search space.
description: This figure displays examples of different board textures used in the POKERBENCH dataset.  Board textures are categories of poker hands based on the types and ranks of community cards (flop cards). The goal is to group similar boards to reduce the complexity of the post-flop game space and improve efficiency. Each example shows a combination of three community cards (the "flop")  categorized by properties such as presence of broadway cards (high value cards), pairs, and the number of cards of the same suit (flush draw potential), which inform the likely strategies a player will use in such situations.  These groupings help reduce the vast number of possible flop scenarios without sacrificing representativeness for model evaluation.
